Text: (7)A reference to a person who is a witness in legal proceedings does not include a reference to a person who is an accused person in criminal proceedings unless he is a witness for the prosecution and a reference to a person who might be, or to a person who has been, a witness in legal proceedings is to be construed accordingly.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)A reference to a person who is or has been a member of staff of an organisation includes a reference to a person who is or has been seconded to the organisation to serve as a member of its staff.

Text: “Property freezing orders (England and Wales and Northern Ireland)U.K.245AApplication for property freezing order(1)Where the enforcement authority may take proceedings for a recovery order in the High Court, the authority may apply to the court for a property freezing order (whether before or after starting the proceedings).

Text: (2)A property freezing order is an order that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An application for a property freezing order may be made without notice if the circumstances are such that notice of the application would prejudice any right of the enforcement authority to obtain a recovery order in respect of any property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The court may make a property freezing order on an application if it is satisfied that the condition in subsection (5) is met and, where applicable, that the condition in subsection (6) is met.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The first condition is that there is a good arguable case—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The second condition is that, if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: the authority has taken all reasonable steps to do so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 245BVariation and setting aside of order(1)The court may at any time vary or set aside a property freezing order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If the court makes an interim receiving order that applies to all of the property to which a property freezing order applies, it must set aside the property freezing order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If the court makes an interim receiving order that applies to some but not all of the property to which a property freezing order applies, it must vary the property freezing order so as to exclude any property to which the interim receiving order applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)If the court decides that any property to which a property freezing order applies is neither recoverable property nor associated property, it must vary the order so as to exclude the property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Before exercising power under this Chapter to vary or set aside a property freezing order, the court must (as well as giving the parties to the proceedings an opportunity to be heard) give such an opportunity to any person who may be affected by its decision.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Subsection (5) does not apply where the court is acting as required by subsection (2) or (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 245CExclusions(1)The power to vary a property freezing order includes (in particular) power to make exclusions as follows—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Exclusions from the prohibition on dealing with the property to which the order applies (other than exclusions of property from the order) may also be made when the order is made.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An exclusion may, in particular, make provision for the purpose of enabling any person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)An exclusion may be made subject to conditions.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Where the court exercises the power to make an exclusion for the purpose of enabling a person to meet legal expenses that he has incurred, or may incur, in respect of proceedings under this Part, it must ensure that the exclusion—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The court, in deciding whether to make an exclusion for the purpose of enabling a person to meet legal expenses of his in respect of proceedings under this Part—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)If excluded property is not specified in the order it must be described in the order in general terms.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)The power to make exclusions must, subject to subsection (6), be exercised with a view to ensuring, so far as practicable, that the satisfaction of any right of the enforcement authority to recover the property obtained through unlawful conduct is not unduly prejudiced.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)Subsection (8) does not apply where the court is acting as required by section 245B(3) or (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 245DRestriction on proceedings and remedies(1)While a property freezing order has effect—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If a court (whether the High Court or any other court) in which proceedings are pending in respect of any property is satisfied that a property freezing order has been applied for or made in respect of the property, it may either stay the proceedings or allow them to continue on any terms it thinks fit.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If a property freezing order applies to a tenancy of any premises, no landlord or other person to whom rent is payable may exercise the right of forfeiture by peaceable re-entry in relation to the premises in respect of any failure by the tenant to comply with any term or condition of the tenancy, except with the leave of the court and subject to any terms the court may impose.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Before exercising any power conferred by this section, the court must (as well as giving the parties to any of the proceedings concerned an opportunity to be heard) give such an opportunity to any person who may be affected by the court's decision.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)In the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (c. 29), after section 255 insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “Prohibitory property orders (Scotland)U.K.255AApplication for prohibitory property order(1)Where the enforcement authority may take proceedings for a recovery order in the Court of Session, the authority may apply to the court for a prohibitory property order (whether before or after starting the proceedings).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A prohibitory property order is an order that—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An application for a prohibitory property order may be made without notice if the circumstances are such that notice of the application would prejudice any right of the enforcement authority to obtain a recovery order in respect of any property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The court may make a prohibitory property order on an application if it is satisfied that the condition in subsection (5) is met and, where applicable, that the condition in subsection (6) is met.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The first condition is that there is a good arguable case—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The second condition is that, if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: the authority has taken all reasonable steps to do so.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255BVariation and recall of prohibitory property order(1)The court may at any time vary or recall a prohibitory property order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If the court makes an interim administration order that applies to all of the property to which a prohibitory property order applies, it must recall the prohibitory property order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If the court makes an interim administration order that applies to some but not all of the property to which a prohibitory property order applies, it must vary the prohibitory property order so as to exclude any property to which the interim administration order applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)If the court decides that any property to which a prohibitory property order applies is neither recoverable property nor associated property, it must vary the order so as to exclude the property.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Before exercising power under this Chapter to vary or recall a prohibitory property order, the court must (as well as giving the parties to the proceedings an opportunity to be heard) give such an opportunity to any person who may be affected by its decision.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Subsection (5) does not apply where the court is acting as required by subsection (2) or (3).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255CExclusions(1)The power to vary a prohibitory property order includes (in particular) power to make exclusions as follows—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Exclusions from the prohibition on dealing with the property to which the order applies (other than exclusions of property from the order) may also be made when the order is made.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An exclusion may, in particular, make provision for the purpose of enabling any person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)An exclusion may be made subject to conditions.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)An exclusion may not be made for the purpose of enabling any person to meet any legal expenses in respect of proceedings under this Part.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If excluded property is not specified in the order it must be described in the order in general terms.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)The power to make exclusions must be exercised with a view to ensuring, so far as practicable, that the satisfaction of any right of the enforcement authority to recover the property obtained through unlawful conduct is not unduly prejudiced.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)Subsection (7) does not apply where the court is acting as required by section 255B(3) or (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255DRestriction on proceedings and remedies(1)While a prohibitory property order has effect the court may sist any action, execution or other legal process in respect of the property to which the order applies.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If a court (whether the Court of Session or any other court) in which proceedings are pending in respect of any property is satisfied that a prohibitory property order has been applied for or made in respect of the property, it may either sist the proceedings or allow them to continue on any terms it thinks fit.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Before exercising any power conferred by this section, the court must (as well as giving the parties to any of the proceedings concerned an opportunity to be heard) give such an opportunity to any person who may be affected by the court's decision.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255EArrestment of property affected by prohibitory property order(1)On the application of the enforcement authority the Court of Session may, in relation to moveable recoverable property to which a prohibitory property order applies (whether generally or to such of it as is specified in the application), grant warrant for arrestment.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)An application under subsection (1) may be made at the same time as the application for the prohibitory property order or at any time thereafter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Such a warrant for arrestment may be granted only if the property would be arrestable if the person entitled to it were a debtor.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A warrant under subsection (1) has effect as if granted on the dependence of an action for debt at the instance of the enforcement authority against the person and may be executed, recalled, loosed or restricted accordingly.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)An arrestment executed under this section ceases to have effect when, or in so far as, the prohibitory property order ceases to apply in respect of the property in relation to which the warrant for arrestment was granted.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If an arrestment ceases to have effect to any extent by virtue of subsection (5) the enforcement authority must apply to the Court of Session for an order recalling or, as the case may be, restricting the arrestment.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 255FInhibition of property affected by prohibitory property order(1)On the application of the enforcement authority, the Court of Session may, in relation to the property mentioned in subsection (2), grant warrant for inhibition against any person specified in a prohibitory property order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)That property is heritable property situated in Scotland to which the prohibitory property order applies (whether generally or to such of it as is specified in the application).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The warrant for inhibition—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Section 155 of the Titles to Land Consolidation (Scotland) Act 1868 (c. 101) (effective date of inhibition) applies in relation to an inhibition for which warrant is granted under subsection (1) as it applies to an inhibition by separate letters or contained in a summons.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)An inhibition executed under this section ceases to have effect when, or in so far as, the prohibitory property order ceases to apply in respect of the property in relation to which the warrant for inhibition was granted.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If an inhibition ceases to have effect to any extent by virtue of subsection (5) the enforcement authority must—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “299Appeal against decision under section 298(1)Any party to proceedings for an order for the forfeiture of cash under section 298 who is aggrieved by an order under that section or by the decision of the court not to make such an order may appeal—

Text: “Threshold amountsU.K.339AThreshold amounts(1)This section applies for the purposes of sections 327(2C), 328(5) and 329(2C).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The threshold amount for acts done by a deposit-taking body in operating an account is £250 unless a higher amount is specified under the following provisions of this section (in which event it is that higher amount).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)An officer of Revenue and Customs, or a constable, may specify the threshold amount for acts done by a deposit-taking body in operating an account—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Where the threshold amount for acts done in operating an account is specified under subsection (3) or this subsection, an officer of Revenue and Customs, or a constable, may vary the amount (whether on a request from the deposit-taking body or otherwise) by specifying a different amount.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Different threshold amounts may be specified under subsections (3) and (4) for different acts done in operating the same account.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)The amount specified under subsection (3) or (4) as the threshold amount for acts done in operating an account must, when specified, not be less than the amount specified in subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)The Secretary of State may by order vary the amount for the time being specified in subsection (2).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)For the purposes of this section, an account is related to another if each is maintained with the same deposit-taking body and there is a person who, in relation to each account, is the person or one of the persons entitled to instruct the body as respects the operation of the account.”

Text: Textual AmendmentsF105S. 125(6) repealed (1.12.2020) by Sentencing Act 2020 (c. 17), s. 416(1), Sch. 28 (with ss. 413(4)(5), 416(7), Sch. 27); S.I. 2020/1236, reg. 2Commencement InformationI90S. 125 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(m)126Harassment etc. of a person in his homeE+W(1)After section 42 of the Criminal Justice and Police Act 2001 (c. 16) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “42AOffence of harassment etc. of a person in his home(1)A person commits an offence if—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)that he should do something that he is not under any obligation to do;
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)knows or ought to know that his presence is likely to result in the harassment of, or to cause alarm or distress to, the resident; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)is likely to result in the harassment of, or to cause alarm or distress to, any such person.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person falls within this subsection if he is—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The references in subsection (1)(c) and (d) to a person's presence are references to his presence either alone or together with that of any other persons who are also present.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)For the purposes of this section a person (A) ought to know that his presence is likely to result in the harassment of, or to cause alarm or distress to, a resident if a reasonable person in possession of the same information would think that A's presence was likely to have that effect.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person guilty of an offence under this section shall be liable, on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51 weeks or to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale, or to both.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)In relation to an offence committed before the commencement of section 281(5) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003 (alteration of penalties for summary offences), the reference in subsection (5) to 51 weeks is to be read as a reference to 6 months.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In this section “dwelling” has the same meaning as in Part 1 of the Public Order Act 1986.”

Text: Textual AmendmentsF130Words in s. 153(1) substituted (7.10.2013) by Crime and Courts Act 2013 (c. 22), s. 61(2), Sch. 8 para. 161(2); S.I. 2013/1682, art. 3(v)F131Words in s. 153(2) omitted (1.11.2019) by virtue of The Motor Vehicles (Compulsory Insurance) (Miscellaneous Amendments) Regulations 2019 (S.I. 2019/1047), reg. 1, Sch. 1 para. 33 (with reg. 5)F132Words in s. 153(3)(a)(b) substituted (7.10.2013) by Crime and Courts Act 2013 (c. 22), s. 61(2), Sch. 8 para. 161(3); S.I. 2013/1682, art. 3(v)F133Words in s. 153(4) omitted (7.10.2013) by virtue of Crime and Courts Act 2013 (c. 22), s. 61(2), Sch. 8 para. 161(4); S.I. 2013/1682, art. 3(v)Commencement InformationI108S. 153 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(u)154Power to require specimens of breath at roadside or at hospital etc.E+W(1)Section 6D of the Road Traffic Act 1988 (preliminary tests for drink and drugs: arrest) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)After subsection (1) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(1A)The fact that specimens of breath have been provided under section 7 of this Act by the person concerned does not prevent subsection (1) above having effect if the constable who imposed on him the requirement to provide the specimens has reasonable cause to believe that the device used to analyse the specimens has not produced a reliable indication of the proportion of alcohol in the breath of the person.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)After subsection (2) insert—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2A)A person arrested under this section may, instead of being taken to a police station, be detained at or near the place where the preliminary test was, or would have been, administered, with a view to imposing on him there a requirement under section 7 of this Act.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Section 7 of that Act (provision of specimens for analysis) is amended as follows.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)For subsection (2) substitute—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: “(2)A requirement under this section to provide specimens of breath can only be made—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2A)For the purposes of this section “a relevant breath test” is a procedure involving the provision by the person concerned of a specimen of breath to be used for the purpose of obtaining an indication whether the proportion of alcohol in his breath or blood is likely to exceed the prescribed limit.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2B)A requirement under this section to provide specimens of breath may not be made at or near a place mentioned in subsection (2)(c) above unless the constable making it—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2C)Where a constable has imposed a requirement on the person concerned to co-operate with a relevant breath test at any place, he is entitled to remain at or near that place in order to impose on him there a requirement under this section.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2D)If a requirement under subsection (1)(a) above has been made at a place other than at a police station, such a requirement may subsequently be made at a police station if (but only if)—

Text: Textual AmendmentsF138Words in s. 156 title substituted (1.4.2013) by The Police and Fire Reform (Scotland) Act 2012 (Consequential Provisions and Modifications) Order 2013 (S.I. 2013/602), art. 1(2), Sch. 2 para. 48(14)(a)F139Words in s. 156(1) substituted (1.4.2013) by The Police and Fire Reform (Scotland) Act 2012 (Consequential Provisions and Modifications) Order 2013 (S.I. 2013/602), art. 1(2), Sch. 2 para. 48(14)(b)F140Words in s. 156(3) omitted (1.11.2019) by virtue of The Motor Vehicles (Compulsory Insurance) (Miscellaneous Amendments) Regulations 2019 (S.I. 2019/1047), reg. 1, Sch. 1 para. 35 (with reg. 5)Commencement InformationI111S. 156 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.S.I. 2005/358, art. 2(b)Local policing informationE+W157Publication of local policing informationE+WAfter section 8 of the Police Act 1996 (c. 16) insert—

Text: “8ALocal policing summaries(1)As soon as possible after the end of each financial year, every police authority established under section 3 shall issue a report for members of the public in the authority's area on matters relating to the policing of that area for the year.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Such a report is referred to in this section as a “local policing summary”.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The Secretary of State may by order specify matters which are to be included in a local policing summary.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A police authority shall arrange—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)It shall be the duty of a police authority, in preparing and publishing a local policing summary, to have regard to any guidance given by the Secretary of State about the form and content of local policing summaries and the manner of their publication.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Before making an order under subsection (3), and before giving any such guidance as is referred to in subsection (5), the Secretary of State must consult—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)This section shall apply in relation to the Metropolitan Police Authority as it applies to a police authority established under section 3.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)A statutory instrument containing an order under subsection (3) shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F159(7A)The following provisions, so far as they extend to Northern Ireland, come into force on such day as the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland may by order appoint—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)Otherwise, this Act comes into force on such day as the Secretary of State may by order appoint.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)Different days may be appointed for different purposes or different areas.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)The Secretary of State may by order make such provision as he considers appropriate for transitory, transitional or saving purposes in connection with the coming into force of any provision of this Act.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (11)The power conferred by subsection (10) is exercisable by the Scottish Ministers (rather than the Secretary of State) in connection with any provision of this Act which comes into force by order made by the Scottish Ministers.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: [F160(12)The power conferred by subsection (10) is exercisable by the Department of Justice in Northern Ireland (rather than the Secretary of State) in connection with any provision of this Act which comes into force by order made by the Department of Justice.]
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Subject to the following provisions, this Act extends to England and Wales only.

Text: (5)The following extend also to Northern Ireland—

Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)The following have the same extent as the enactments to which they relate—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (8)So far as Schedule 17 contains a repeal or revocation of an enactment which corresponds to the repeal or revocation of that enactment by another provision of this Act, that Schedule and section 174(2) have the same extent as that other provision.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (9)So far as they relate to any provision of this Act which extends to any place outside the United Kingdom, sections 172, 173, 177, 178 and this section also extend there.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (10)Subsection (2) does not apply to the following—

Text: Commencement InformationI309Sch. 9 para. 9 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(j)ProspectiveStaff custody officersE+WF18910E+W. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .Textual AmendmentsF189Sch. 9 para. 10 repealed (12.1.2009) by Policing and Crime Act 2009 (c. 26), s. 116(6)(b), Sch. 8 Pt. 13Section 144SCHEDULE 10E+W+N.I.Parental compensation orders Part 1 E+WEngland and Wales1E+WThe Crime and Disorder Act 1998 (c. 37) is amended as provided in paragraphs 2 to 5.Commencement InformationI310Sch. 10 para. 1 in force at 20.7.2006 for specified purposes by S.I. 2006/1871, art. 22E+WAfter section 13 insert—“13AParental compensation orders(1)A magistrates' court may make an order under this section (a “parental compensation order”) if on the application of a local authority it is satisfied, on the civil standard of proof—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The condition is that the child has taken, or caused loss of or damage to, property in the course of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A parental compensation order is an order which requires any person specified in the order who is a parent or guardian of the child (other than a local authority) to pay compensation of an amount specified in the order to any person or persons specified in the order who is, or are, affected by the taking of the property or its loss or damage.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)The amount of compensation specified may not exceed £5,000 in all.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)The Secretary of State may by order amend subsection (4) above so as to substitute a different amount.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)For the purposes of collection and enforcement, a parental compensation order is to be treated as if it were a sum adjudged to be paid on the conviction by the magistrates' court which made the order of the person or persons specified in the order as liable to pay the compensation.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)In this section and sections 13B and 13C below, “local authority” has the same meaning as in the 1989 Act.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 13BParental compensation orders: the compensation(1)When specifying the amount of compensation for the purposes of section 13A(3) above, the magistrates' court shall take into account—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If property taken is recovered before compensation is ordered to be paid in respect of it—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The court shall specify in the order how and by when the compensation is to be paid (for example, it may specify that the compensation is to be paid by instalments, and specify the date by which each instalment must be paid).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)For the purpose of ascertaining the means of the parent or guardian, the court may, before specifying the amount of compensation, order him to provide the court, within such period as it may specify in the order, such a statement of his financial circumstances as the court may require.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person who without reasonable excuse fails to comply with an order under subsection (4) above is guilty of an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 3 on the standard scale.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)If, in providing a statement of his financial circumstances pursuant to an order under subsection (4) above, a person—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: he is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding level 4 on the standard scale.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)Proceedings in respect of an offence under subsection (6) above may, despite anything in section 127(1) of the 1980 Act (limitation of time), be commenced at any time within two years from the date of the commission of the offence or within six months of its first discovery by the local authority, whichever period expires earlier.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 13CParental compensation orders: supplemental(1)Before deciding whether or not to make a parental compensation order in favour of any person, the magistrates' court shall take into account the views of that person about whether a parental compensation order should be made in his favour.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Before making a parental compensation order, the magistrates' court shall obtain and consider information about the child's family circumstances and the likely effect of the order on those circumstances.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)Before making a parental compensation order, a magistrates' court shall explain to the parent or guardian of the child in ordinary language—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)A magistrates' court which has made a parental compensation order may make an order under subsection (5) below if while the order is in force—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)An order under this subsection is an order discharging the parental compensation order or varying it—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)Where an application under subsection (4) above for the discharge of a parental compensation order is dismissed, no further application for its discharge shall be made under that subsection by any person except with the consent of the court which made the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (7)References in this section to the magistrates' court which made a parental compensation order include any magistrates' court acting in the same local justice area as that court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 13DParental compensation orders: appeal(1)If a magistrates' court makes a parental compensation order, the parent or guardian may appeal against the making of the order, or against the amount of compensation specified in the order.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The appeal lies to the Crown Court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)On the appeal the Crown Court—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)Any order of the Crown Court made on an appeal under this section (other than one directing that an application be re-heard by a magistrates' court) shall, for the purposes of section 13C above, be treated as if it were an order of the magistrates' court from which the appeal was brought and not an order of the Crown Court.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person in whose favour a parental compensation order is made shall not be entitled to receive any compensation under it until (disregarding any power of a court to grant leave to appeal out of time) there is no further possibility of an appeal on which the order could be varied or set aside.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 13EEffect of parental compensation order on subsequent award of damages in civil proceedings(1)This section has effect where—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The damages in the civil proceedings shall be assessed without regard to the parental compensation order, but the claimant may recover only an amount equal to the aggregate of the following—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The claimant may not enforce the judgment, so far as it relates to such a sum as is mentioned in subsection (2)(b) above, without the permission of the court.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)if he is not a senior officer, the chief officer under whose direction and control he is; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (ii)if he is not a senior officer, the chief officer under whose direction and control he is;”; and
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)After subsection (1) insert—“(1A)In this Part “the relevant officer”, in relation to a DSI matter, means the person serving with the police (within the meaning of section 12(7))—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: and where there is more than one such person it means, subject to subsection (1B), the one who so dealt with him last before the death or serious injury occurred.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (1B)Where it cannot be determined which of two or more persons serving with the police dealt with a person last before a death or serious injury occurred, the relevant officer is the most senior of them.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI327Sch. 12 para. 10 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)11E+WSchedule 3 (handling of complaints and conduct matters) is amended as set out in the following paragraphs.Commencement InformationI328Sch. 12 para. 11 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)12E+WAfter paragraph 14 insert— “Part 2A E+Whandling of death and serious injury (DSI) matters14ADuty to record DSI matters(1)Where a DSI matter comes to the attention of the police authority or chief officer who is the appropriate authority in relation to that matter, it shall be the duty of the appropriate authority to record that matter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)If it appears to the Commission—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: the Commission may direct the appropriate authority to record that matter; and it shall be the duty of that authority to comply with the direction.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 14BDuty to preserve evidence relating to DSI matters(1)Where—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: it shall be the duty of that authority to secure that all such steps as are appropriate for the purposes of Part 2 of this Act are taken, both initially and from time to time after that, for obtaining and preserving evidence relating to that matter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Where—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: it shall be his duty to take all such steps as appear to him to be appropriate for the purposes of Part 2 of this Act for obtaining and preserving evidence relating to that matter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)The chief officer's duty under sub-paragraph (2) must be performed as soon as practicable after he becomes aware of the matter in question.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)After that, he shall be under a duty, until he is satisfied that it is no longer necessary to do so, to continue to take the steps from time to time appearing to him to be appropriate for the purposes of Part 2 of this Act for obtaining and preserving evidence relating to the matter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)It shall be the duty of a police authority to comply with all such directions as may be given to it by the Commission in relation to the performance of any duty imposed on it by virtue of sub-paragraph (1).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)It shall be the duty of the chief officer to take all such specific steps for obtaining or preserving evidence relating to any DSI matter as he may be directed to take for the purposes of this paragraph by the police authority maintaining his force or by the Commission.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 14CReference of DSI matters to the Commission(1)It shall be the duty of the appropriate authority to refer a DSI matter to the Commission.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)The appropriate authority must do so within such period as may be provided for by regulations made by the Secretary of State.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A matter that has already been referred to the Commission under this paragraph on a previous occasion shall not be required to be referred again under this paragraph unless the Commission so directs.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 14DDuties of Commission on references under paragraph 14C(1)It shall be the duty of the Commission, in the case of every DSI matter referred to it by a police authority or a chief officer, to determine whether or not it is necessary for the matter to be investigated.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Where the Commission determines under this paragraph that it is not necessary for a DSI matter to be investigated, it may if it thinks fit refer the matter back to the appropriate authority to be dealt with by that authority in such manner (if any) as that authority may determine.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI333Sch. 12 para. 17 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)18E+WIn paragraph 20(1) (restrictions on proceedings pending the conclusion of an investigation), after “22” insert “ or 24A ”.Commencement InformationI334Sch. 12 para. 18 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)F19519E+W. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .Textual AmendmentsF195Sch. 12 para. 19 omitted (31.1.2017 for specified purposes, 1.2.2020 in so far as not already in force) by virtue of Policing and Crime Act 2017 (c. 3), s. 183(1)(5)(e), Sch. 5 para. 48(b); S.I. 2020/5, reg. 2(n) (with reg. 3(1)(2)(4))20E+WAfter paragraph 21 insert—“21A“Procedure where conduct matter is revealed during investigation of DSI matter(1)If during the course of an investigation of a DSI matter it appears to a person appointed under paragraph 18 or designated under paragraph 19 that there is an indication that a person serving with the police (“the person whose conduct is in question”) may have—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: he shall make a submission to that effect to the Commission.

Text: (2)If, after considering a submission under sub-paragraph (1), the Commission determines that there is such an indication, it shall—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)If during the course of an investigation of a DSI matter it appears to a person appointed under paragraph 16 or 17 that there is an indication that a person serving with the police (“the person whose conduct is in question”) may have—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: he shall make a submission to that effect to the appropriate authority in relation to the DSI matter.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)If, after considering a submission under sub-paragraph (3), the appropriate authority determines that there is such an indication, it shall—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)Where the appropriate authority in relation to the person whose conduct is in question—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: it shall record the matter under paragraph 11 as a conduct matter (and the other provisions of this Schedule shall apply in relation to that matter accordingly).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI335Sch. 12 para. 20 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)21E+WFor paragraph 22 (final reports on investigations) substitute—“22“Final reports on investigations: complaints, conduct matters and certain DSI matters(1)This paragraph applies on the completion of an investigation of—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person appointed under paragraph 16 shall submit a report on his investigation to the appropriate authority.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person appointed under paragraph 17 or 18 shall—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)In relation to a DSI matter in respect of which a determination has been made under paragraph 21A(2) or (4), the references in sub-paragraphs (2) and (3) of this paragraph to the appropriate authority are references to—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (5)A person designated under paragraph 19 as the person in charge of an investigation by the Commission itself shall submit a report on it to the Commission.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (6)A person submitting a report under this paragraph shall not be prevented by any obligation of secrecy imposed by any rule of law or otherwise from including all such matters in his report as he thinks fit.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI336Sch. 12 para. 21 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)22(1)In the heading preceding paragraph 23, after “investigation report” insert “ under paragraph 22 ”.E+W(2)In paragraph 23(1)—(a)in paragraph (a), for “(2)” substitute “ (3) ”; and(b)in paragraph (b), for “(3)” substitute “ (5) ”.(3)After paragraph 23(12) insert—“(13)In relation to a DSI matter in respect of which a determination has been made under paragraph 21A(2) or (4), the references in this paragraph to the appropriate authority are references to the appropriate authority in relation to the person whose conduct is in question.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI337Sch. 12 para. 22 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)23(1)In the heading preceding paragraph 24, after “investigation report” insert “ under paragraph 22 ”.E+W(2)In paragraph 24(1)—(a)in paragraph (a), for “22(1)” substitute “ 22(2) ”; and(b)in paragraph (b), for “22(2)” substitute “ 22(3) ”.(3)After paragraph 24(10) insert—“(11)In relation to a DSI matter in respect of which a determination has been made under paragraph 21A(2) or (4), the references in this paragraph to the appropriate authority are references to the appropriate authority in relation to the person whose conduct is in question.”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: Commencement InformationI338Sch. 12 para. 23 in force at 1.7.2005 by S.I. 2005/1521, art. 3(1)(w)24E+WAfter paragraph 24 insert—“24A“Final reports on investigations: other DSI matters(1)This paragraph applies on the completion of an investigation of a DSI matter in respect of which neither the Commission nor the appropriate authority has made a determination under paragraph 21A(2) or (4).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)A person appointed under paragraph 16, 17 or 18 or designated under paragraph 19 shall—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (3)A person submitting a report under this paragraph shall not be prevented by any obligation of secrecy imposed by any rule of law or otherwise from including all such matters in his report as he thinks fit.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (4)On receipt of the report, the Commission shall determine whether the report indicates that a person serving with the police may have—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 24BAction by the Commission in response to an investigation report under paragraph 24A(1)If the Commission determines under paragraph 24A(4) that the report indicates that a person serving with the police may have—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: it shall notify the appropriate authority in relation to the person whose conduct is in question of its determination and, if it appears that that authority has not already been sent a copy of the report, send a copy of the report to that authority.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Where the appropriate authority in relation to the person whose conduct is in question is notified of a determination by the Commission under sub-paragraph (1), it shall record the matter under paragraph 11 as a conduct matter (and the other provisions of this Schedule shall apply in relation to that matter accordingly).
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: 24C(1)If the Commission determines under paragraph 24A(4) that there is no indication in the report that a person serving with the police may have—
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: it shall make such recommendations or give such advice under section 10(1)(e) (if any) as it considers necessary or desirable.
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv

Text: (2)Sub-paragraph (1) does not affect any power of the Commission to make recommendations or give advice under section 10(1)(e) in other cases (whether arising under this Schedule or otherwise).”
Source: Serious Organised Crime and Police Act 2005 (c. 15).csv
